SECRET.
G.T.5365
BATTLE SITUATION - EVENING - 9th AUGUST, 1918.
WESTERN FRONT.
To-day the Franco-British Armies have made considerable further progress en the AMIENS battle front. Owing to indifferent visibility news is slew in coming back.
The line appears to run approximately as follows:- East of PIERREPONT, east of CONTOIRE, south of HANGEST-EN-SANTERRE? ARV1LLERS, BEAUFORT, WARVILLERS, ROSIERES (doubtful), HARBONNIERES; MORCOURT, west of CHIPILLY, MORLANCOURT. The presence of British troops in ROSIERES is not definitely established.
Prisoners taken by the British exceed 13,000 whilst the French have so far counted over 4,000 prisoners.
200 guns have been taken by the British.
The enemy continues to evacuate his forward positions in the LYS VALLEY. Our line has been advanced on the whole front from the LAWE RIVER to the RIVER BOURRE, northwest of MERVILLE, to a maximum depth of over 2,000 yards. Our troops hold LOON, LE-CORNET-MALO, QUENTIN LE PETIT PACAUT and LE SART.
We carried out a successful local operation last night north, of KEMMEL, advancing our line a short distance on a front of more than 1,000 yards and capturing ever 30 prisoners.
On the French front the situation is generally unchanged.
2. ITALIAN AND MACEDONIAN FRONTS.
There is nothing to report.
General Staff,
War Office, S.W.1.
9th August, 1918.
Issued at 6.45 p.m.
